title: 113_hr3593
content: The Act may be cited as the "VA Construction Assistance Act of 2014". It includes findings and the sense of Congress. Congress finds that major medical center construction projects of the Department of Veterans Affairs have experienced significant schedule delays averaging 35 months, with cost increases of $336 million per project. Management oversight for projects in Denver, Orlando, and New Orleans should be handled by a special project manager from the Army Corps of Engineers. The Army Corps of Engineers project manager, independent of the Department of Veterans Affairs, has seen major medical center construction projects with continuous delays and a cost increase of nearly $1 billion. Congress believes the management of these projects has been a failure and urges the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to implement recommendations to improve construction procedures. Implementation of major medical facility construction reforms. Section 8104 of title 38, United States Code is amended to include requirements for projects such as using a medical equipment planner, developing a project management plan, construction peer excellence review, metrics program for change-order processing, and utilizing design-build processes where possible. The amended Section 8104 of title 38, United States Code includes requirements for construction projects at major medical facilities, emphasizing the use of design-build processes to minimize change orders. SEC. 4. SPECIAL PROJECT MANAGER FOR CERTAIN MEDICAL CENTER CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must appoint a special project manager with experience in managing construction projects over $60,000,000 to oversee covered projects until completion. The manager will conduct oversight of all construction-related operations, including the Department of Veterans Affairs' performance with prime contractors and compliance. The special project manager appointed by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will oversee compliance with Federal Acquisition Regulation, advise on construction activities, and recommend best practices for project operations. Within 90 days of appointment, the manager must submit detailed plans for the covered project to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The special project manager appointed by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide progress reports every 180 days to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing the project's advancements and any changes made by the Department. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide progress reports every 180 days to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs, detailing changes made by the prime contractor, communication and working relationship analysis, and recommendations for improving construction-related activities. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide necessary information and administrative assistance to a special project manager for major medical facility projects. The term "covered projects" refers to construction projects outlined in a report by the Comptroller General of the United States. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide information and assistance for major medical facility projects identified by the Comptroller General of the United States. These projects have not been activated to accept patients as of the enactment of this Act in April 2013. SEC. 5. PROHIBITION ON NEW APPROPRIATIONS. No additional funds authorized for this Act and its amendments. Funds to be used from existing allocations.
